As the person in the previous review wrote, I too have the same problem. My workaround in KDE Plasma was to go into the system settings tool, select Default Appliications, and manually select Brave from the drop-down list of browsers. Other than that, all seems to be working as expected, and no other issues found in my first day of testing. As such, I am giving four stars for now.

Brave Browser is a mixed bag that offers several notable features alongside some significant drawbacks. Here's a breakdown of its pros and cons:

Pros:
* Privacy-Focused: Brave stands out for its strong emphasis on privacy. It blocks ads and trackers by default, providing a smoother and more secure browsing experience.
* Speed: The browser is impressively fast, owing to its ad-blocking capabilities and efficient performance optimizations.

Cons:
* Reward System: Brave Rewards allows users to earn cryptocurrency (BAT) for viewing privacy-respecting ads, which can be an appealing feature for some users.
* Web3 and Crypto Integration: While Brave's built-in Web3 and cryptocurrency features, including the Brave Wallet and integrated LEO AI systems, may appeal to crypto enthusiasts, they add unnecessary complexity for those who don't use these technologies.
* Resource Intensive: The comprehensive suite of features makes the browser heavier than its competitors. This can lead to slower performance on less powerful machines and may be a dealbreaker for users seeking a lightweight browsing solution.
* Learning Curve: The additional features and settings can be overwhelming for new users, making it less user-friendly compared to more streamlined browsers.

Conclusion:
Brave Browser has a lot to offer, especially for users who prioritize privacy and are interested in the cryptocurrency space. However, the built-in Web3 and crypto features, along with the LEO AI systems, can make it feel bloated. If only Brave offered a lighter version without these extras, it could potentially be the perfect browser. For now, it's a solid option but not without its compromises.
summary: Jam packed of features most people don't want

description: At least a browser that lets you use the same window decorations that you have on your native app windows.
summary: At last. a browser that allows window decorations

description: I cannot use Brave Browser on Vanilla OS

It isn't the best in term of privacy, and there might be concern about the company behind it, but it has great privacy features while still maintaining many of the best features from full-featured Chromium browsers (some of which are rebuilt to be more privacy-respecting, such as the Sync system).

Checked with EFF's Cover Your Tracks and it has pretty good results - though user-agent (and platform - both of which can be spoofed), webgl-vendor, and system fonts remains an issue, but the randomization works good enough apparently.

I'd recommend if ungoogled-chromium and Firefox doesn't work for you, and I strongly prefer this over Vivaldi still.
summary: A good balance between privacy and practicality

Its the brave browser, but my big problem is that once again this is another flatpak from flathub with NO sandbox control for the home directory but control for Wayland and x11 audio and more.

If you want a browser with tor in flatpak use the tor browser in flathub which actually has control over the sandbox for your home.

THIS is the future of flatpak. Advertise privacy, security but you get no control over those things.

Works on Steam Deck in both desktop and gamemode. Brave has built in ad blocking.

Some settings do not populate in gaming mode on Steam Deck. I switch to desktop mode and no issues. For simply browsing, possibly 1 of the best. No forced updates like Firefox. Interface & basics, ie home page, are easily editable. Although I would like to be able to edit tab location & bookmark bar, its security features outweigh its middling customization.

The Browser Comes Up With A Error Of Sync Not Working
Sync Works Fine On The Non Beta Version

Brave could not access your operating system's safe storage. This is what's used to secure data such as passwords and cookies; it's also required for Brave Sync to connect your browser profile between devices. This means Brave Sync is not running. To resolve this issue, please see the Brave Sync troubleshooting guide.

Uses same web engine as Chrome and is fully compatable with anything meant to run on Chrome. The benifit is that it has privacy by default and built in ad block which works amazingly well. Better than using plugins like uBlockOrigin, AdBlockPlus, PrivacyBadger, Ghostery (Please dont ever use Ghostery, its a data miner!), and NoScript.

I have used many browsers over the years, Brave has been the best end user experience of all of them. This should be the default browser for everyone.

comes with duckduckgo and brave search engines by default which are the best google alternatives that currently exist. Also has optional torrent client, Tor network support, and crypto wallet (you can get rid of crypto stuff if you dont want)

I noticed whenever I use Brave it makes my laptop's fans often turn on. The Chrome engine seems to be hard on my laptop which is surprising because it has 64 GB of memory and an Intel i5 CPU. Maybe an i5 is too weak for running this browser. Nonetheless, I uninstalled the browser. I am going back to Firefox because it does not activate my fans.

description:
Great alternative to chromium or google chrome. 
Perfect for privacy concerned people who do want to have a chrome based browser.

Brave ist ein sicherer Webbrowser, der eine schnelle und sichere Surferfahrung bietet. Es ist ein Open-Source-Browser, der auf Chromium basiert und eine Rehe von Funktionen bietet, die Ihnen helfen, Ihre Privatsphäre und Sicherheit zu schützen. Brave blockiert automatisch Werbung und Tracker, die versuchen, Ihre Daten zu sammeln. Brave bietet auch eine integrierte VPN-Funktion, die Ihnen hilft, Ihre IP-Adresse zu verbergen und Ihre Online-Aktivitäten zu schützen. Darüber hinaus bietet Brave eine integrierte Suchmaschine, die Ihnen hilft, sichere und vertrauenswürdige Websites zu finden.
